image.altText: A woman stands with a fence in front of her with a neutral/serious expression.

props.synopsis: Obesity experts and patient groups are concerned an over-reliance on body mass index (BMI) is leading to some people being abandoned by the health system and denied life-changing surgery or treatment.

title.children: Belinda could barely walk, but was told to lose weight for life-changing knee replacement surgery

image.altText: Bridget McKenzie sits at a table for an interview on Kitchen Cabinet

props.synopsis: One of the Coalition's most senior politicians says the way her government treated former Australia Post boss Christine Holgate was a defining moment for when women turned away from the Liberal-National government.

title.children: 'Humiliating personally and professionally': Bridget McKenzie opens up about losing her dream job

image.altText: A 14-year-old boy screams, sitting on the floor as two men whose faces are blurred push him.

props.synopsis: Children with autism spent hours with staff in padded rooms, where they were sometimes sat on and held down by adults as part of a controversial NDIS-funded therapy.

title.children: Jadon wouldn't sit on a cushion, so staff in 'Severe Behaviour' shirts stepped in to force him

image.altText: Premier Jeremy Rockliff in a blue suit and light blue tie stands up in parliament and gestures with his hand as he speaks.

props.synopsis: The release of the 3,500-page report is a turning point in the long road for justice for the many victim-survivors who have come forward to tell their stories of abuse at the hands of paedophile teachers, nurses, carers or others working within state institutions.

title.children: Tasmanian premier tables long-awaited child abuse report after horrific hearings

image.altText: An older white man in a suit and glasses smiles in front of a white photo backdrop.

props.synopsis: McCallum died Monday of natural causes surrounded by family at New York Presbyterian Hospital, TV network CBS said in a statement.

title.children: David McCallum, star of hit TV series The Man From U.N.C.L.E. and NCIS, dies aged 90

image.altText: A balding man in a blue suit, no tie, arm-in-arm, with a woman in a dark red plung dress.

props.synopsis: Emma Heming Willis says dementia "is a family disease" that has ripple effects for the person diagnosed and their loved ones.

title.children: Bruce Willis's wife says 'it's hard to know' if he is aware of his dementia

image.altText: A woman sits looks directly into the camera while sitting in a lounge room.

props.synopsis: Pauline Weldon-Bowen takes legal action against NSW Police Force claiming she was discriminated against because of her race and gender, in a case her lawyer says highlights a culture of unconscious bias.

title.children: Sydney woman sues police over how she was treated when she reported an alleged road rage

image.altText: Brisbane Lions player Lachie Neale smiles while standing behind a podium with the Brownlow Medal on a screen behind him.

props.synopsis: Ten years after playing in his first grand final, Lachie Neale is preparing for a second with a completely different game that has put him in lofty heights as a two-time Brownlow medallist.

title.children: Lachie Neale joins an elite club with his second Brownlow Medal. Here's how he did it

image.altText: Kim Jong Un leans over a table, looking through a magnifier as he points a gun.

props.synopsis: While its northern rival has a nuclear vessel at its disposal, South Korea is relying on another strategy to scare its neighbours: an elite special forces operation unit trained to work behind enemy lines. Here's how it works.

title.children: If Kim Jong Un declares war, South Korea's 'decapitation unit' triggers the 'kill chain'

image.altText: A man lies in hospital with a tube coming from his nose

props.synopsis: Efforts are underway to save the Gold Coast surfing champion who is critically ill in a Bali hospital.

title.children: Rush on for rare blood donations to help save surfing great Mark Richardson

image.altText: A boy waves a flag over his head in amongst a huge crowd, some with Australian flags

props.synopsis: Today marks 40 years since a yacht club few had ever heard of, from an obscure city Down Under, ended the longest winning streak in any sport in an unlikely victory that rocked the sporting establishment.

title.children: The day Australia II ended the longest winning streak in world sporting history and united the nation in celebration

image.altText: The hand of a man in a suit checking the ASX website on his phone at the ASX.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market has fallen to its lowest level since July 10, while the US dollar rises to a 10-month high on bets interest rates may stay higher for longer than investors had expected. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX slips to 11-week low, Wall Street snaps four-day losing streak

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas shares are losing value as pressure mounts on the Chairman Richard Goyder to step down. The airline has also warned higher fuel costs may push ticket prices up. Analyst firm Jefferies has lowered its earning per share (EPS) forecast for Qantas by 14 per cent, but says 'positive' customer improvement initiatives along with ongoing strength in demand suggest damage to the brand is fixable. By 12:15pm AEST, Qantas' share price was down 1.5% t o $5.15. It looks even worse when you step back at look at Qantas shares. They have dropped 5.3% in the past week, and have plunged 17.3% in the past month.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas shares in nosedive

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hi everyone — Rachel Pupazzoni jumping in to say hi. The leader on the ASX today is medical imaging company Pro Medicus after securing a $140 million, 10-year contract with the largest not-for-profit healthcare system in Texas, Baylor Scott & White Health. Its shares jumped 9.3 per cent at the open, but have pared back a little to 9 per cent — to be valued at $77.62 a share, shortly after 11am AEST. Pro Medicus will supply cloud-engineered imaging services, starting in the first quarter of 2024. "Baylor Scott & White Health joins our impressive list of IDN and Tier 1 academic clients and represents our first major client in Texas." Dr Sam Hupert, the chief executive of Pro Medicus, told the market: "The scale and scope of our initiative with Baylor Scott & White Health is noteworthy and will include nearly 500 radiologists who will be exposed to the benefits of Visage 7."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Imaging company Pro Medicus secures $140m contract

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Putting my hi-vis on for a moment... and further to Dave's earlier post about Gina Rinehart increasing her stake in lithium miner Liontown to more than 10 per cent, its shares have taken a hit this morning. The company is among the bottom 10 performers on the ASX 200 so far, having fallen 2.67 per cent to $2.92 a share. Today's trading session is also the first time shareholders have been able to react to Ms Rinehart's near $200 million shopping spree. So, perhaps not all of them are happy with having her as a bigger shareholder! This is going to be one to watch over the coming weeks.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Liontown shares tumble after Rinehart stake increases

image.altText: Upper body photo of Bill Shorten pointing directly ahead as he speaks.

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: 'I don't know what makes a chair resign': Shorten weighs in on Qantas. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says he was very disturbed to learn of unlawful practices used against children with autism and intellectual disabilities by a controversial NDIS funded therapy service. In a video aired on the ABC's Four Corners program, a teenager is shown being pinned face-down by six workers in protective headgear at Irabina Autism Services in Melbourne as part of its 'Severe Behaviour Program'. The program ceased in 2021, and Irabina has since been acquired by new owners. Anthony Albanese says he has not seen the footage, but the audio he heard was "very confronting". "Some of the - what I take was - audio from the footage... I found it very disturbing. And I know that the NDIS Minister, Bill Shorten, will be responding appropriately to that," he said. You can read the full Four Corners investigation by Anne Connolly, Amy Donaldson and Jessica Longbottom by tapping the link below. You can also catch up anytime on ABC iview .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM 'disturbed' by latest Four Corners investigation

featuredLink.title: Jadon wouldn't sit on a cushion, so staff in 'Severe Behaviour' shirts stepped in to force him

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says Qantas has a lot of work to do in terms of repairing damage to its reputation. As we've reported on throughout the morning, the Australian and International Pilot's Association is calling for Qantas chairman Richard Goyder to resign, saying the association has "totally lost confidence" in him, and questions if the company can move forward under his leadership. Two weeks ago, the company was found by the High Court to have illegally sacked 1,700 ground crew staff during the pandemic. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the airline is an important Australian brand. "What we know is Qantas has a lot of work to do to repair the damage that has been done to its reputation both in terms of workers and in terms of customers," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM says Qantas has 'a lot of work to do' in rebuilding reputatation

children.content: says Qantas has a lot of work to do in terms of repairing damage to its reputation.

props.alt: A close up of Albanese gesturing as he speaks.

children.content: As we've reported on throughout the morning, the Australian and International Pilot's Association is calling for Qantas chairman
to resign, saying the association has "totally lost confidence" in him, and questions if the company can move forward under his leadership.
Two weeks ago, the company was found by the High Court to have illegally sacked 1,700 ground crew staff during the pandemic.
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the airline is an important Australian brand.
"What we know is Qantas has a lot of work to do to repair the damage that has been done to its reputation both in terms of workers and in terms of customers," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Details of a strike-ending deal between Hollywood writers and studios are yet to be made public, but writers are confident it will address their concerns about the use of artificial intelligence. Screenwriters are expected to return to work soon, after they reached a deal with studios  — though it's yet to get final approval. Emmy-nominated television writer and Writers Guild of America captain, Zack Bornstein, says writers need protection from AI. "We are on the front lines of defending humans as labour," he said. "As crazy as that sounds, we need to codify that certain things can only be done by human beings. "It's so wild, we just need to make sure that generative AI and all the other kinds of other AI you can't use it to replace writers."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hollywood writers confident strike-ending deal includes protection from AI

props.alt: A screengrab of Stranger Things with Eleven standing at the front of the group, with Will by her side.

children.content: Production on the next season of Stranger Things was halted due to the strike.

image.altText: phoebe running thumb
